ANITA WOOD: I am thrilled,
and it is my pleasure to introduce you to our guest
speaker today, Pedram Mokrian.

Pedram, in this
webinar, we'll describe

why AI has become
such a high priority and how business leaders
can think about developing

and adopting AI solution. He will provide an
overview of the key AI

terms, concepts, trends that
inform business strategy.

Along with advising
companies around the world on entrepreneurship,
business model disruption,

and technology
innovation strategy, Pedram teaches
courses at Stanford through the School
of Engineering.

And he teaches the XDGT224,
Building an AI-Enable

Organization Force, which is
part of the Stanford Digital Transformation Program.

Before we begin, for
our audience, please remember you can enter
in a question at any time

and we do encourage you to
submit your questions earlier during this webinar.

With that, I'm going to hand
the webinar over to Pedram. Pedram, welcome and thank
you for being with us today.

PEDRAM MOKRIAN: Well, thanks
so much for having me. It's a delight to talk about
one of my favorite topics.

And it's strange, even though
I'm not a computer scientist and I'm not classically
trained in AI

itself, for me to not only
teach a course on the topic, but to even come and
speak to you all about it.

So I just wanted to
start by giving you a bit of a background as to
what is my relationship with AI

and how it all came to be. Back in the day, a
long, long, long time ago, I used to be
a chip designer.

In fact, my focus was on
computer architecture. And it was fascinating to
understand how computers work.

And it's really interesting
also to then start to think about how do you
apply that context to how

the world works and
how the world operates. And so, in fact, how
I got into Stanford for graduate school
in the first place

was predicated on my
desire to apply at the time

were called evolution-based
algorithms to risk management and to asset prices.

And so it was taking
an engineering approach to think about how
markets actually operated.

Now, if you think
about that context, this is going back a couple
of decades now at this point-- aging myself--

the interesting thing
was the world of AI as we know it today
and machine learning and all the different models
that are being used in practice

weren't as prevalent. And so it was still viewed
with some skepticism around this notion of this
dark art and this dark science

or of AI and machines that
can kind of think on their own to help with how the
world actually operates.

Many years later, I actually
stepped into the world of venture capital. And that's really
when the art of AI

was getting implemented
deeply inside of a lot of new and emerging
technology companies.

And one of the most
fascinating ways to understand how
AI gets applied is to view it through the
lens of an entrepreneur.

People that have an
understanding of what the technology can
do and are thinking about how to solve
problems, specifically

in the greater
good of the world, to take these innovations
and these concepts, productize them, and
then take them to market.

So a lot of what I'm going
to share with you is not only what I've seen and
what I've dealt

with from an
entrepreneur's perspective as an investor helping them
understand how to create these businesses, but also on
the other side of things is,

as Anita pointed
out, I also advise a number of large
companies and helping them understand how can they
start to then incorporate

some of these technologies
into their practice on a daily basis. So without further
ado, I'm going to dive

in to our topic of
discussion today, which begins with a big overview of
this notion of data and AI.

And the first thing
that I wanted to say is, the reason that I
get excited about putting this course together
in the first place

is because I was seeing this
divergence of conversations

happening in the world of AI. There's a lot of people
that were technologists that we're talking about
the deep technologies

and the emerging
algorithms of AI and how they can put that
to practice into use.

So think about this as being
sort of an AI ecosystem driven by technologists
speaking to technologists.

And sometimes that's not
very useful for people that are trying to get an
understanding of what's going on.

On the other side,
there's people that are talking at
such a high level that it's almost like a
very, very big macro view.

But you really don't know how
these technologies get applied to that because there's
a huge gap in terms

of that understanding. And so the course
itself is really driven around giving
you a perspective that's

not so entrenched and
ingrained in terms of the technology
itself, but it's not just a very big altruistic view
of what AI could do either.

It's really about a practical
understanding of what it means and some technical terminologies
and some examples around how

to think about what
is the difference between supervised and
unsupervised learning, and how can that
be useful for you.

Well, as a manager
or somebody who's leading a project
like this, it's always good to at least be
well versed in the big picture

and then leave the details to
the people that are experts. But if there's a disconnect
between you not even

understanding what it
even means to think about supervised learning
or how it even works, well then, you're not going to
have the good level of empathy

to actually be able to drive
these projects forward. And then the last
part of that is

going to be focused on
the strategy, right? How do we think about that? Which is core to a
lot of the things that I do in and around
innovation, which

is to just define and
describe strategies for things that may appear to be
abstract or hard to deal with.

So I want to begin with
something that I do actually in a lot of my
innovation talks, which

is talk about this thing called
the Dunning-Kruger Effect. And for those of you that
are familiar with it, you'll recognize the curve.

And for those of you that
aren't, what I like to do is to frame this in terms
of a very simple 2 by 2.

And think about understanding
of a human being or an organization.

If we don't really
understand it at all, that's what the x-axis
is representing, right?

Versus we have some
experience with the topic or we're experts in the topic. How does that relate
to our confidence?

What you would anticipate
is that something like this is a linear curve, which
says while the more confident

we are about something, then
the greater chance of us being an expert in
it and vice versa. The more expertise we have
about a subject matter, the more

confidence we should have. Well, the amazing thing
about this research was that it unearthed a
very interesting pattern

and it actually looks like this. And they did this with a
lot of graduate students, where at the beginning,
they had so much confidence

and so much excitement. But then the more they learned
about the topic and the more that they internalized all that
knowledge, even though they're

becoming better and better
at the topic and the subject matter and becoming
bigger experts in it,

their confidence was
actually dropping. And I actually
overlay this in terms of where I think the
notion of AI and innovation

and bringing new things
falls into this danger zone of a lot of organizations.

At first, its ecosystems
and people and organizations that know nothing
about the subject.

They're just very confident
because they've read an article or seen something on TV. Great.

Take that enthusiasm,
but now let's actually bolt on practice
and expertise and confidence.

The other side of
it is organizations that have so much
entrenched capabilities, but because they've seen
some of the dark side of what

can go wrong, they actually
end up handcuffing themselves and they don't have the
courage and the confidence

to actually go and
pursue these things. Because it might not
have worked in the past, and so they're bringing all of
those legacy thoughts with them

as we go forward. This, unfortunately, is the
exact same thing with AI.

Because a lot of people don't
really understand what it is, it's almost like a dark
science, you can basically say,

we'll throw AI at the
problem and we'll solve it. That gets us into
the first bucket.

On the other side, because this
subject matter has been around for decades and a lot of
times it hasn't actually

yielded promising results, a
lot of people then also then assume that, well,
here we go again.

It's not going to
work this time either. And it throws us into
the middle bucket, where the observations
of history

are actually tainting what our
capabilities are going forward. And it's extremely
important as managers

to understand where
also you are and how to deflect some
of the criticism, even though you know that
the world has changed.

But at the same time, how
to temper the enthusiasm when you know, for
example, that it's not just

around throwing
around buzzwords, it's actually about
building systems that work. And so hopefully, this
program gives you a sense
of how to think about that. So why is this important today?

Well, there's an aspirational
goal that a lot of people think about, which is how to
become more digital and more

digitally enabled,
and how to shift towards this notion of being
a digital operating company.

Now, we've seen this in terms
of a lot of tech companies take on this model,
where you have almost

like this nonlinear exponential
value creation opportunity that expands with the more
data that you have

and the more users
that you might have, especially in the world
of consumer internet. That a traditional
operating model only

scales in terms of the
efficiencies of scale, but not because of the
fact that you're actually generating some outsized
value because of the data

that you're collecting. And so as a result
of this, this is where we want to start to
then think about how do we

take advantage of
that underlying data to create this, hopefully,
aspirational exponential value

creation opportunity
going forward? Which brings us to
this term, alpha.

Alpha is used in public
markets and financial markets to think about an
investment strategy that

beats the market, right? It's your edge. It's your secret
sauce, if you will.

It's associated
with your ability to create excess returns. And so the way that
we want to start

to think about this is,
how can we gain alpha? How can we become better than
what the market could typically

do based on some unfair
advantage and some secret sauce that we might have? And in many instances,
this is data.

So as we start to reflect
back on that exponential value creation opportunity,
that effectively

reflects that company's
alpha, its secret sauce. So if you go back in
time and actually look

at value creation in general and
how companies have historically thought about
creating alpha, we've

migrated from organizations
that view outsized returns being driven by their assets, right?

So for example, think
about land use rights or the assets associated
with factories

or stores or real estate. These are physical properties
and equipment inventory

and the like, right? Which effectively
gives you the ability to then go and pursue market
opportunities because you

had those assets under control. Several decades ago, we
started to shift that model

and we started to say,
well, you can also get outsized returns by thinking
about intellectual property,

which is your unique expertise
in your knowledge of the world and how you can actually
drive your understanding

and your intellect
within your organization to then start to drive
these outsized returns. And you can think about
things like patents.

And you can think about things
like trade secrets, when it comes to things, for example,
like manufacturing or chip

design, where you have an unfair
advantage because of knowledge.

As we start to now shift
into what a lot of people refer to as the fourth
Industrial Revolution and thinking about data, this
is where information is now

starting to become your IP
of the past, if you will, your unfair advantage
to generate alpha.

And this is a very,
very important process and understanding from
a business perspective

before we even start
to talk about AI. Because one of the
underpinning elements of AI

today, especially, is
your access to data, is your ability to
think about, how

can we actually
leverage the data that we have either access to
the data that we're creating

or the data that we can
actually acquire and make use of for whatever
reason that might

be to then make that
as part of our AI strategy, our unfair advantage?

How can we use data
to drive alpha? And that really is
the underlying premise

of how we should be thinking
strategically around applying AI for
business decisions

and for business applications. Now, we mentioned this
fourth Industrial Revolution.

We can then overlay
that in terms of what has happened historically.

Well, what's
happened historically is if you go back to one of the
most well-studied and oldest

ecosystems in the
world, namely England, that's been studied,
what we've seen

here is that the English
economy grew linearly

with population over
centuries and then something interesting happened.

And you can imagine
what that is. There is an inflection point.

That inflection point started
to drive an exponential economy.

And this maps up neatly
against what we commonly

refer to as the Industrial
Revolutions, the first, the second, the third.

And now we are in the
dawn of the fourth. And this is exactly how
we should be thinking

about this use of data. So where we went from
manual labor, manual work,

to mechanized work,
driven by steam engines and then driven by electricity
and then driven by,

over time, more
machinery, you started to create outsized returns and
outsized capabilities that you

couldn't have done otherwise. And then as a
result of that, you made the previous
generation of doing

things, of manufacturing
and procurement, of service delivery, obsolete.

This is where we are
today is to think about, how can we then take
advantage of the tool sets

that we have
available to us today to continue this evolution?

Much the same way
that several decades ago, we couldn't even imagine
what the internet could be,

right? When I grew up, email
was just taking off. People just-- I
mean, we literally

could have made up any
email address on any server because there wasn't that
many people using email. Again, I'm dating myself.

But now you can
start to then imagine what would the world look
like without the internet? How would you even do commerce
or conduct any regular business

without this notion of the
internet available to you? One day soon,
we're going to have

the same type of conversations
around the use of data and intelligence.

And so the further we are
ahead of that curve, the more strategically placed
we'll be to take

advantage of all the riches
that can come with it. And again, a lot of this
has to do with data.

So, where are we now? Why are we talking about
this digital transformation?

There's a confluence
of things that are happening
simultaneously that are driving this conversation.

And sometimes it's
just one thing. For example, it's electricity.

But in other times,
it's actually a series of things that
need to come together exactly at the right time
before the value starts

to become realized. And what we'll talk
about this notion of AI, specifically, this
subject matter

has been around for a long time. And in fact, in
the course, we'll talk about a little brief
history of it as well.

It's been around for decades. But the other
elements of this that are really driving this
transformative change

haven't been. And this is what makes this
whole thing so interesting.

So the underlying
capabilities that we have from computational
perspectives and infrastructure,
cloud computing,

we haven't had this for
decades and decades. We haven't had this
plethora of data

that we have access to
for decades and decades. And now as we
start to then think about this broad
access of IoT devices,

the internet of things,
and sensors and sensor data and the ability for us
to actually generate data

from the environment, from
our physical ecosystem, becoming unbelievably
cheap to the point

where it's almost
practically free now. All of these are
coming now together

to create this digital
transformation revolution that we're witnessing today.

And we're witnessing this not
just in the tech ecosystem. We're now starting
to witness this

across all different domains. And so for just a quick snapshot
of what that looks like,

there's a recent
study by McKinsey and company that was
around, how do we even think about the value
of AI versus just

traditional analytics that
we might have had before? And the incremental
value is literally

in the trillions of dollars. And as you can see here,
it's across virtually

every single ecosystem
that you can imagine. So irrespective of where
you're coming from,

you should be thinking
outside the box. In fact, in many cases,
as I was told recently, you should be thinking
without the box.

Imagine a world where you
can then think about the data and how you can connect that
data to value, independent

of the fact that you
may not be coming from a technology-based
company, but you have access to this alpha
that you can then leverage.

Now, whether it's banking or
insurance or pharma or retail, all of these incredibly
large ecosystems all

stand to gain from
the impact of AI. And again, taking advantage of
all these different things that

are coming together
from cloud computing to data to actually the new
technologies and new algorithms

that are being created even on
a daily basis in and around AI.

So, one thing that
you may be thinking of is, I've been throwing
around this concept

of artificial intelligence
in AI for quite some time. What does it mean?

How do you define it? It's actually one of
the core components and one of the things that
I found quite rewarding

when I was actually creating
this course in the first place is going to people that
are truly experts in it

and asking them what
they think about AI and how do they define it. And you'd be surprised that
the definition is isn't always

as clear as you would
hope it would be. There are a few definitions
that I will throw at you

and then we'll reserve
some of the insights in the course itself. But generally speaking, it's
a branch of computer science

that deals with intelligent
behavior and computers. So it's typically
the way to think

about that is, how does a
computer system perform tasks that normally require
human intelligence to do

such as, for example,
visual perception or speech recognition or decision making? And how do we then
actually create

a mechanism by which
the computer can do that instead of the human being?

And it's funny. It's one of those things where
the more we go back in history,

the more we can
start to then take things that are daily
things that we don't even

think twice about, and then
apply this definition of I and then think about,
well, hmm, would that

have been AI back when
it was first introduced? And there's a couple
of images here

I'm sharing with
you from the 1940s, in fact, where this was
just common practice

on a daily basis. You had switchboard operators. You had elevator operators. You had people that were
doing these manual tasks that

required some level
of intelligence to do. And then they were
replaced with automation.

Think about somebody
that picked up a phone that was used to
speaking with somebody and saying, I need
to speak with mister

And missus so-and-so and then
they get dispatched to it. Or I need to speak with
a certain department and they get dispatched
to that because somebody

was interpreting that. And now think about that then
being replaced effectively with automation.

It's magic for somebody that
can then just basically say, magically, I got connected
to the right person

via this notion of automation. And so at the time of
adoption, it's very difficult

to discern the difference. But over time, we just
take it for granted.

Now the other way of
thinking about sort of this element of
automation, as we start to think about
this incorporation of AI,

is also to then
understand, more broadly speaking, the spectrum of AI.

From narrow to super. And this is where I think
a lot of confusion sets in.

So what happens in
a lot of instances where I speak with business
leaders that are not necessarily technologists
and they think about AI,

they project onto the
conversation things that they've seen
in movies, right?

These robots that do
these magical things. And you can ask them
anything about anything and then they can basically
make decisions and unearth

the information for
you and stuff happens.

But the reality is we actually
live in a world of narrow AI today, right?

And if you think about something
as basic as a Roomba, which I'm sure many of you own and
sometimes you own two of them

because they get a little
bit smarter over time, this is also AI, right?

This is also how we
start to then think about AI-powered
devices and tools.

Now, is this the cutting
edge or the bleeding edge? In many cases, it is.

In many cases, the
bleeding edge of AI enables us to do
very simple tasks,

but to do them in a repeatable,
potentially safe way that we couldn't
have done otherwise.

Where we start to incorporate
different elements of sensing, different elements of
actuation, different elements

of potentially decision-making,
that a very simple device needs to take into
account before it

can conduct something as
basic as wiping popcorn off the floor.

So we really need
to contextualize what do we mean when we
start to think about AI. We're talking about this
very broad definition

that we might see in movies
that that's a little bit outside of the realm of reality.

Or are we starting
to think about, how can we take the things
that are ready today

and start to then
put them to use? And we are really much more
closer to this narrow AI world

today before we start to then
think about generalizing. And so unless you're
a technology company,

such as like a
Google or a Facebook, that basically has entire server
farms devoted to this topic

and has more data than
you can even imagine, it doesn't really
make much sense for us

to start to think about
general applications towards traditional
business opportunities.

And so I don't want
to dampen expectations of what is possible
today, but unless we

can start to then confine
and bound our definitions, we're not going to be able
to get out of our own way.

We're going to be stuck
in that first part of the Dunning-Kruger
effect curve that I showed you about, where
it's all about enthusiasm

and nothing about execution. Now, why am I
describing all of this?

Why are we even
talking about AI when we start talking about the
power of data to begin with?

Well, one of the key
things for us to understand is in order for us to go
through this true digital

transformation, it
means we have to have a greater reliance on data.

It's going to be almost
like a broken record, so I apologize in advance if
I speak about data little bit too much.

But it's true. It's the engine. It's the fuel that
makes everything work.

Now, the problem that
we've had with data is if you rely on
it too much, you

could draw the
wrong conclusions. Because you may be
looking at it just from a pure
statistical perspective

without any broader
understanding of the context of it. But if we then eliminate
the use of data at all

and then just basically do the
gut feel management style that may have worked
historically, well, we're

not necessarily then
taking advantage of these unforeseen
relationships that may actually

have a lot of information,
a lot of insights that we can actually
take advantage of. And so it's the blending
and the balancing

of being able to
understand how to use data and how to still maintain
our understanding

of a hypothesis-driven
approach to making decisions and to creating outcomes
that becomes powerful.

And so this is the
approach that we want to start to take as we
start to then think about,

how do we build an AI system? How do we start to
incorporate part

of that hypothesis-oriented
approach that we're very comfortable
with, while at the same time

we start to then take
advantage of data? And here is a very
simple framework.

And again, I want to apologize. It might seem too
simple and it might appear a little bit
weird and wonky,

but it's actually
helped me a lot when I thought about this
notion of applying AI

and as I tried to
coach and mentor both entrepreneurs, students,
technologists, business

leaders alike, on how
to think about it. And I typically try
to think about it

is a three-legged stool.  So to me, this becomes
a very simple framework

to think about
the basic building blocks of an AI system. And we'll get into
all kinds of details inside the course itself
around all of these things.

But I just want to shed light
on a couple of these key issues. So there are three legs to this
stool, as you can see, right?

One is data. The second are the algorithms. So where are we in
terms of our ability

to manipulate the
data as well, right? And how sophisticated
are the algorithms that we have access to.

And then the third
is the platforms, which is our ability to actually
compute and to take advantage

of the algorithms
on top of the data, but in an efficient, timely,
and economically feasible way.

These support the
problem definition. In much like a
three-legged stool,

which the legs by themselves
don't really add the value. It's the seat that you sit
on that is really the core.

That's the same thing that
I want you to take away from this conversation. This building block
has to begin with, what

are you trying to do first? Defining the problem, defining
the purpose of why you're even

pulling these things together. So it's like a stool
without a seat. It's just three legs.

They don't really
do anything for you. The seat is what
brings us all together and actually creates the
value proposition, right?

The legs you need to
make sure that it just doesn't topple over, right? So you don't have
a one-legged stool.

But I really want you to think
about the problem definition

as your starting point. And much like entrepreneurship
or innovation,

the first building
block should be about, what problem are
you trying to solve? What is the key
market motivation?

What is the customer motivation? Whether your customer is
internal to your organization or external to your
organization, as in somebody

that you actually are serving,
what is their motivation? What are they seeking?

What problem are they
looking to solve? What are the domains of
things that we can think

about that we could
enhance for them? Now, again, your customer could
be an internal organization

or it could be truly
somebody that you're serving as part of
your organization outside of the company.

But it's really important to
start to then think about, what problem is it
that we're really trying to solve for here?

From there, we then
shift through the legs. We start to then think about
data and what kind of data

do we have access to? How do we start to think about
the kind of data that we have and how does that
become useful to us?

How do we start to think
about this difference between structured
and unstructured data? Where structured
data is something

that is already
very well organized. It's in tabular formats. We may be collecting it via
our existing systems already.

And then unstructured
data is all of the stuff that is just
kind of flowing to us that's not tabular, right?

It's not necessarily
organized in a way that is really accessible or
machine readable or analyzable

via spreadsheet or
traditional type of algorithm. And how do we start to think
about this entire universe

of data that can
then fuel our ability to think about generating these

And that's really, really
the important thing. From there, obviously, it takes

that we want to use.

Those are decisions
that should be made by the technical experts. And then, obviously, what is the

that we can actually

algorithms are really

predicated on two things. One is on the
modern world of data

and the large volumes of data

of machine intelligence.

And so for the
final few minutes, I just want to touch
on a couple of things around machine intelligence.

Specifically, machine learning. A lot of people
confuse and conflate

AI and machine learning. And so just very, very
simply, machine learning

is a subfield of
artificial intelligence. It enables computers
to learn on their own.

And the machine-learning
algorithms allow us to identify
patterns and observe data to build the models and
then to explain the world

and to predict things without
having to a priori explicitly

program those rules into place. The typical example of
how to think about this

is to observe a child. It's based on the same concept,
where through trial and error

and through observation
and through outcome, a child does not
necessarily know how

to manipulate their fingers. They do that by observing, over
time, these actions until they

can refine it and hone
that skill in a much more complex way as they continue to
learn and to incorporate this

as part of their psyche, as
part of their decision making, as part of their
general intelligence.

And so it's this
response to experiences. It's a similar type
of thing that we want to then think
about conveying

in terms of
traditional programming to machine learning-based
programming. So traditional
programming, a computer

is instructed in a
very specific way to carry out a set
of tasks, right? So you understand what
it does, you program it.

It's almost like the child. It's born with an
understanding of how to manipulate the
thumb and forefinger and to do things
in high precision.

And guess what? It doesn't continue to learn
from that because it basically is stuck with whatever
you taught it.

So it doesn't actually
get better over time. So if you think about
a child, it first learns to pick up one thing.

And then the more
sophisticated it becomes as it learns
how to manipulate this particular
skill set, it learns

how to manipulate it

what the system can do. With machine learning, we set
